entry.title: Publications
entry.summary: Peer-reviewed conference publications Non-peer-reviewed publications Non-peer-reviewed presentations Continuing professional development (CPD) workshops held Maynooth University, Wed 22nd March 2023 (5pm - 8pm) CT4T Generalisation Maynooth University, Wed 8th March 2023 (5pm - 8pm) CT4T Evaluation and logic Maynooth University, Wed 1st March 2023 (5pm -…
entry.content:
Peer-reviewed conference publications

    • Taina Lehtimäki, Rosemary Monahan, Kevin Casey, Aidan Mooney, and Thomas J. Naughton. 2023.
      A computational thinking obstacle course based on Bebras tasks for K-12 schools.
      In Proceedings of the 28th ACM Conference on on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education (ITiCSE '23). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, pp. 478–484. DOI:10.1145/3587102.3588775
Supplementary material:
      •  
CT Obstacle Course teacher feedback form
  • Taina Lehtimäki, Rosemary Monahan, Aidan Mooney, Kevin Casey, and Thomas J. Naughton. 2023.
    Computational thinking resources inspired by Bebras.
    In Proceedings of the 28th ACM Conference on on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education (ITiCSE '23). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, p. 663. DOI:10.1145/3587103.3594203
  • Taina Lehtimäki, James Hamm, Aidan Mooney, Kevin Casey, Rosemary Monahan, and Thomas J. Naughton. 2022.
    A computational thinking module for secondary students and pre-service teachers using Bebras-style tasks.
    In Proceedings of the 2022 Conference on United Kingdom & Ireland Computing Education Research (UKICER '22). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, Article No. 19, p. 1. DOI:10.1145/3555009.3555030
  • Taina Lehtimäki, Rosemary Monahan, Aidan Mooney, Kevin Casey, and Thomas J. Naughton. 2022.
    Bebras-inspired computational thinking primary school resources co-created by computer science academics and teachers.
    In Proceedings of the 27th ACM Conference on on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education Vol. 1 (ITiCSE '22). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, pp. 207–213. DOI:10.1145/3502718.3524804
  • James Lockwood and Aidan Mooney. 2018.
    Developing a computational thinking test using Bebras problems.
    In Joint Proceedings of the CC-TEL 2018 and TACKLE 2018 Workshops, co-located with 13th European Conference on Technology Enhanced Learning (EC-TEL 2018), Leeds, UK, Article No. 1, pp. 1–12.
  • Aidan Mooney, Joseph Duffin, Thomas Naughton, Rosemary Monahan, James Power, and Phil Maguire. 2014.
    PACT: An initiative to introduce computational thinking to second-level education in Ireland.
    Irish Conference on Engaging Pedagogy (ICEP 2014). Athlone Institute of Technology, Ireland, pp. 1–14.

Non-peer-reviewed publications

  • Taina Lehtimäki, Liam Jordon, Robert Cleary, Thomas Naughton. 2022.
    Teacher notes: Computational thinking workbook for 3rd to 6th class.
    Maynooth University, County Kildare, Ireland, 2022. ISBN (Electronic) 978-1-9998055-8-6.
  • Taina Lehtimäki, Thomas Naughton, Aidan Mooney, Kevin Casey, and Rosemary Monahan. 2022.
    Computational thinking workbook for 3rd to 6th class.
    Maynooth University, County Kildare, Ireland, 2022. ISBN (Print) 978-1-9998055-4-8 ISBN (Electronic) 978-1-9998055-5-5.
  • Thomas Naughton, Aidan Mooney, Rosemary Monahan, Kevin Casey, Joseph Duffin, Liadh Kelly, Charles Markham. 2019.
    Bebras-related/-inspired activities in Maynooth University 2018-2019.
    15th International Bebras Task Workshop, Balatonkenese, Hungary, May 2019.

Non-peer-reviewed presentations

  • Taina Lehtimäki, "Online computational thinking module for transition year," CSLinc CPD TY module presentation, Online, 19th April 2023.
  • Taina Lehtimäki, "Teaching computational thinking ​through active games​," Computers in Education Society of Ireland Annual Conference (CESICON 2023), Atlantic Technical University, Galway City, 11th March 2023.
  • Rosemary Monahan and Taina Lehtimäki, "Online computational thinking module ​for transition year," MathsMeet Conference 2022, Maynooth University, Maynooth, 15th October 2022.
  • Taina Lehtimäki, "Online computational thinking module ​for transition year," Computers in Education Society of Ireland Annual Conference (CESICON 2022), Online, 5th March 2022.
  • Taina Lehtimäki, Rosemary Monahan, and Thomas Naughton, "Interactive computational thinking workshop for primary and secondary school teachers," Computers in Education Society of Ireland Annual Conference (CESICON 2021), Online, 27th February 2021.
  • Thomas Naughton and Taina Lehtimäki, "Workshops on computational thinking using Bebras tasks," CESI TeachMeet, Athlone, Ireland, 28th February 2020.

Continuing professional development (CPD) workshops held

  • Maynooth University, Wed 22nd March 2023 (5pm - 8pm) CT4T Generalisation
  • Maynooth University, Wed 8th March 2023 (5pm - 8pm) CT4T Evaluation and logic
  • Maynooth University, Wed 1st March 2023 (5pm - 8pm) CT4T Abstraction and algorithms
  • Maynooth University, Sat 25th February 2023 (10am - 4:30pm) CT4T Decomposition, pattern recognition, and representation
  • Maynooth University, Mon 18th July 2022 (9:30am - 12pm) Co-creation workshop (1st-2nd class primary)
  • Maynooth University, Mon 11th July 2022 (10:30am - 1:30pm) Co-creation workshop (1st-2nd class primary)
  • Maynooth University, Mon 4th July 2022 (10:30am - 1:30pm) Co-creation workshop (1st-2nd class primary)
  • Maynooth University, Mon 27th June 2022 (10:30am - 1:30pm) Co-creation workshop (1st-2nd class primary)
  • Maynooth University, Wed 25th May 2022 (11am - 1pm) Introduction to computational thinking
  • Maynooth University, Mon 9th May 2022 (2pm - 4pm) Introduction to computational thinking
  • Online, Tue 30th November 2021 (7pm - 9pm) Christmas-themed tasks
  • Online, Thu 25th November 2021 (3pm - 5pm) Christmas-themed tasks
  • Online, Wed 16th June 2021 (3pm - 6pm) Summer-themed tasks
  • Online, Wed 26th May 2021 (3pm - 6pm) Focus on algorithmic thinking
  • Online, Wed 5th May 2021 (1pm - 4pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Online, Wed 28th April 2021 (1pm - 4pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Online, Wed 14th April 2021 (10am - 1pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Online, Wed 24th March 2021 (3pm - 6pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Online, Wed 12th March 2021 (1pm - 4pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Maynooth University, 28th February 2020 (10am - 2pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
  • Maynooth University, 31st January 2020 (10am - 1pm) Computational thinking in the classroom using Bebras tasks
If you would like to learn more about any of our publications please email us at pact@mu.ie.

entry.title: Links
entry.summary: Bebras International: Bebras is an international initiative aiming to promote Informatics (Computer Science, or Computing) and computational thinking among school students at all ages. Bebras Ireland: The ICS Foundation run the Bebras Challenge on a non-profit basis. The ICS Foundation run many other educational outreach…
entry.content:
Bebras International: Bebras is an international initiative aiming to promote Informatics (Computer Science, or Computing) and computational thinking among school students at all ages.
Bebras Ireland: The ICS Foundation run the Bebras Challenge on a non-profit basis. The ICS Foundation run many other educational outreach projects including Tech Week Ireland and the National Scratch Competition. 
Bebras UK: The home of the UK Bebras Challenge.
The BBC Introduction to computational thinking: Before computers can be used to solve a problem, the problem itself and the ways in which it could be resolved must be understood. Computational thinking techniques help with these tasks.
Barefoot: Barefoot helps you unpack computational thinking quickly and easily, with materials tailored to your Nation's computing curriculum.
SFI Science Week: Throughout Science Week there will be a variety of ways for you to get involved and find out more about our amazing planet through events, interviews, social media and much more
ICSF Tech Week: Tech Week is Ireland's nationwide festival of technology aimed at students, parents and the public.
Smart Futures: Promoting careers in science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM).

entry.title: Beach day
entry.summary: The O'Brien family are spending the day at the beach. The want to find the perfect umbrella. The umbrellas are numbered 1-10. First, they need to be sure the umbrella is free. It is free, if both sunbeds don’t have towels on them. Second, they…
entry.content:
Beach day

 

The O'Brien family are spending the day at the beach. The want to find the perfect umbrella. The umbrellas are numbered 1-10.

First, they need to be sure the umbrella is free. It is free, if both sunbeds don’t have towels on them.

Second, they don’t want to be directly next to where people walk. They can check for footprints in the sand.

Third, they don’t want to be directly next to any wet sand. They can tell if the sand is wet by its darker colour.

Fourth, they don’t want to sit where they will hear music coming from the people next to them. The range of the music is marked on in the pictures with music notes in the squares.

Finally, they want to have some space to play in the sand, at least 2 squares should be enough space.

 

 

 

 

QUESTION

Question: Which umbrella is the best one for the O’Brien family to sit under?

Beach day

TEACHER NOTES

Answer

The correct answer is 7.

Explanation of the answer

This task involves following a set of rules to find the best option.

Umbrella 1 is next to walking areas and in range of music

Umbrella 2 is in range of music.

Umbrella 3 is occupied.

Umbrella 4 is in range of music.

Umbrella 5 next to a walking area.

Umbrella 6 is next to a walking area and in range of music

Umbrella 7 is the perfect place for the O’Brien family.

Umbrella 8 is next to a walking area.

Umbrella 9 is next to a walking area.

Umbrella 10 is next to wet sand.

 

 

 

 

Connection to computational thinking

Algorithms: This task is an example of following an algorithm. The O’Brien family are using the same set of rules to consider each umbrella. By consistently applying the same rules to each umbrella, the correct one can be found.

Decomposition: This task is an example of breaking requires breaking into parts. The O’Brien family can solve this problem one umbrella at a time and in any order. Or they can solve it one rule at a time in any order. By reducing the problem into smaller problems, it can be solved easier.

entry.title: Meet the team
entry.summary: Joe Bloggs: Beaver The world’s most industrious philanthropic beaver, has dedicated his life to improving the lives of fellow woodland creatures. Joan Bloggs: The enigmatic beaver detective, spends his days solving mysteries in the heart of the forest. Joey Bloggs: Beaver spends his days in…
entry.content:
Joe Bloggs: Beaver

The world’s most industrious philanthropic beaver, has dedicated his life to improving the lives of fellow woodland creatures. 

Joan Bloggs:

The enigmatic beaver detective, spends his days solving mysteries in the heart of the forest. 

Joey Bloggs: Beaver

spends his days in his cozy workshop, surrounded by gears, pulleys, and half-finished contraptions. 

Jenkins Bloggs: Beaver

Patrols the serene forest pond, ensuring that all creatures swim safely. She hosts synchronized swimming shows.

Jennifer Bloggs: Beaver

Spends her days deciphering ancient tree rings and uncovering forgotten beaver legends. She claims that the oldest oak in the forest once hosted a beaver disco.

Jenny Bloggs: Beaver

Soars above the treetops in her custom-built wooden airplane, leaving fluffy cumulus clouds in her wake.

Joseph Bloggs: Beaver

Composes haikus while floating downstream. His favorite subjects? Sun-dappled water, lily pads, and the elusive moonbeam fish.

Juniper Bloggs: Beaver

Wields her trusty chainsaw, felling trees with precision. But she’s no ordinary lumberjack—she plants two saplings for every tree she cuts.

Julius Bloggs: Beaver

He emerges from the murky depths when the clock strikes midnight, leaving behind ripples that echo like ghostly whispers.
